clinical_study.official_title: Does Repetitive, Assistive Sit-to-stand Training Facilitate the Independence in Sit-to-stand? A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
Background: Manual lifting is a common method to train the sit-to-stand, in which repetition is important. Alternate training regimen by mechanical device may be opted to avoid staff injury.
Objective: The purpose of the study is to investigate the repetitive mechanical training to improve the independence of standing up.
Methods: A total of 38 participants were randomised into two groups. Both groups had no lesser than 100 repetitions or 10 minutes/day of training sessions. Berg Balance Scale (BBS), Modified Rivermead Mobility Index (MRMI), Sit-and-Reach test (SRT), Five-Repetition Sit-to-Stand Test (5XSST), Sit-to-Stand Test from the Balance Master® (SST) were assessed in baseline, after 5 days and 10 days of training.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- first episode of unilateral stroke with hemiparesis,
- able to understand and follow simple verbal instructions,
- able to sit unsupported for at least two minutes
- unable to stand up independently even with arm support.
Exclusion Criteria:
- they had any other co-morbid neurological diseases or an unstable medical condition.
